# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Integer=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ArgumentError("timezone_bumper can only be applied to DateTime values, not Date."))
    end
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```

This function takes a `DateTime` object and an optional integer `bump` which defaults to 3 hours. It checks if the input is a `Date` type and throws an error if so, as specified in the requirements. If the input is a valid `DateTime`, it increments the time by `bump` hours using the `Dates.Hour` constructor and returns the new `DateTime` value.
